customer_addr:
Dean of College of Natural Resources & Science
Humboldt State University
ARCATA, CA 95521

citations.narrative:
The facility does not have a written contingency plan that contains situations that could adversely impact animals at the
facility, although it does have an emergency action plan for animal escapes. A complete written contingency plan must
identify situations in which animals would be adversely affected, specify tasks to respond to the emergency or disaster,
identify a chain of command, address resources and materials needed for response and recovery. A research facility must
develop, document, and follow an appropriate plan to provide for the humane handling, transportation, housing, and care
of their animals in the event of an emergency or disaster and train their employees on the plan.
Correct by: 10/15/2023

There was an approximately 24 inch by 48 inch section of welded wire with exposed sharp points in an aviary containing
22 ducks, 2 geese, and an American wigeon. The section was located at the bottom of the fence to the left of the entry
door. There was also a 6 inch by 6 inch piece of wire mesh patch in the same location. All of the birds were free in the
aviary with access to the sharp points. The primary enclosure must be constructed and maintained to protect the bird from
injury.
Correct by: 10/15/2023

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
The facility did not have a documented environment enhancement plan to promote psychological well-being of their avian
species as required by the Animal Welfare Act. The facility must develop, document and follow a species appropriate plan
for environmental enhancement adequate to promote the psychological well-being of birds. The plan must be approved by
the attending veterinarian, and at a minimum must address social grouping, environmental enrichment, special
considerations, restraint, and exemptions to the plan regulation and be in accordance with currently accepted professional
standards.
Correct by: 10/15/2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the Attending Vet and the IACUC staff.
Additional Inspectors:
KATHARINE FRANK, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.38(l) 
   
Miscellaneous. 
The facility does not have a written contingency plan that contains situations that could adversely impact animals at the 
facility, although it does have an emergency action plan for animal escapes. A complete written contingency plan must 
identify situations in which animals would be adversely affected, specify tasks to respond to the emergency or disaster, 
identify a chain of command, address resources and materials needed for response and recovery. A research facility must 
develop, document, and follow an appropriate plan to provide for the humane handling, transportation, housing, and care 
of their animals in the event of an emergency or disaster and train their employees on the plan.  
 
Correct by: 10/15/2023 
3.153(a)(1)(i) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
There was an approximately 24 inch by 48 inch section of welded wire with exposed sharp points in an aviary containing 
22 ducks, 2 geese, and an American wigeon. The section was located at the bottom of the fence to the left of the entry 
door. There was also a 6 inch by 6 inch piece of wire mesh patch in the same location. All of the birds were free in the 
aviary with access to the sharp points. The primary enclosure must be constructed and maintained to protect the bird from 
injury.  
 
Correct by: 10/15/2023 
3.154 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
The facility did not have a documented environment enhancement plan to promote psychological well-being of their avian 
species as required by the Animal Welfare Act. The facility must develop, document and follow a species appropriate plan 
for environmental enhancement adequate to promote the psychological well-being of birds. The plan must be approved by 
the attending veterinarian, and at a minimum must address social grouping, environmental enrichment, special 
considerations, restraint, and exemptions to the plan regulation and be in accordance with currently accepted professional 
standards.

Correct by: 10/15/2023 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the Attending Vet and the IACUC staff. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
KATHARINE FRANK, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
